Crimes.Crime_Name: Discreditable conduct under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the doctrine of res judicata or double jeopardy bar disciplinary proceedings under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act after acquittal in U.S. and Canadian courts?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, Section 11(h) of the Charter
Crimes.Application_Facts: RCMP officer disclosed confidential information; acquitted in U.S. and discharged in Canada on criminal charges.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Disciplinary proceedings not barred by double jeopardy.
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Application dismissed; disciplinary proceedings allowed to proceed.
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Double jeopardy under s. 11(h) of the Charter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 11(h) of the Charter applies only to identical offenses
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Nature and purpose of disciplinary proceedings vs. criminal proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for prohibition of disciplinary hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Facts from prior U.S. and Canadian criminal proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 11(h) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Application_Basis: Same underlying facts but distinct legal character of offense
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Prior acquittals and discharge on res judicata grounds
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Disciplinary offenses under RCMP Act are service-specific and distinct from criminal charges
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential harm to officer’s career if disciplined
Crimes.Cause_Description: Officer disclosed confidential information leading to international legal actions and internal discipline
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Relied on established record from prior proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act – discreditable conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No new evidence introduced; reliance on existing facts
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 11(h), Charter; RCMP Act provisions on discipline
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Factual basis accepted; legal distinction upheld
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Disciplinary proceedings serve different purpose than criminal trials
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Doctrine of res judicata does not apply to administrative/disciplinary proceedings

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can an R.C.M.P. officer be tried for a disciplinary offense under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act after being acquitted of similar criminal charges in the U.S. and Canada?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central – matter based on legal interpretation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Judicial records from U.S. and Canadian criminal cases
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 11(h), Charter; RCMP Act disciplinary provisions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged violation of double jeopardy protections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Distinction between criminal prosecution and professional discipline
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether the two proceedings constitute the same offense
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Double jeopardy applies only when offenses are identical in nature
Crimes.Application_Factor: Same conduct, different legal framework and objectives
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Scope of s. 11(h) protection in non-criminal contexts
Crimes.Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Section 11(h) of the Charter does not bar separate disciplinary processes
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Disciplinary charge is service-related, not criminal
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness: Right to full answer and defence in disciplinary process affirmed
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing and legitimacy of disciplinary action post-acquittal

Crimes.Violation_Type: Disclosure of sensitive law enforcement information
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the doctrine of res judicata or double jeopardy bar disciplinary proceedings under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act for conduct already adjudicated in U.S. and Canadian criminal courts?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Application_Facts: Officer acquitted in U.S., criminal charges dismissed in Canada due to res judicata
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Disclosure of confidential police information abroad
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of s. 11(h) Charter right against double jeopardy
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 11(h) protects against second trial for same offense
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Purpose and nature of disciplinary regime under RCMP Act
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Seeking judicial intervention to stop internal discipline
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Records of foreign and domestic criminal proceedings
Crimes.Application_Basis: Same factual matrix but different legal characterization
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Professional misconduct is a separate category from criminal guilt
Crimes.Cause_Description: Officer shared classified information while overseas, triggering cross-border legal responses
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No challenge to authenticity or completeness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal authority over RCMP members’ conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Factual findings from prior cases adopted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Disciplinary proceedings ensure integrity of police force regardless of criminal outcome

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Does the doctrine of res judicata or double jeopardy bar disciplinary proceedings under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act after acquittal in U.S. courts?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Based on same facts as criminal case
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show legal bar to discipline
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 11(h) of the Charter does not prevent distinct disciplinary proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Attempt to enjoin disciplinary process via judicial review
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Double jeopardy following U.S. acquittal and Canadian stay
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Disciplinary process deemed fair and lawful
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: U.S. trial record, Canadian stay of proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter rights balanced against public interest in police integrity
Crimes.Legal_Rule_Source: Supreme Court jurisprudence on double jeopardy
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued that prior outcomes should bar further action
Crimes.Authority: Commissioner of the RCMP, Federal Court oversight
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Abuse of position for personal gain
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Separate sovereign interests justify dual accountability
